title: What is the difference between ordinary and partial differential equations? - Quora

response.answer_text: The answer is hidden in the terms itself. Ordinary differential equations deal with the relation between derivatives of a function of a single scalar variable. For instance, [math] \frac{d^2 y}{d x^2} + \frac{dy}{dx} + y = \exp(x).[/math] Here y is a function of x only. On the other hand, partial differential equations deal with the variation of a function of many variables, like a function u of two variables x and y. The following is an example of a partial differential equation. [math]\frac{\partial u}{\partial x} + \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} = 0[/math] Here [math]\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}[/math] is the rate of change of u with respect to x only (similarly for y).

Differential equations which involve only one independent variable and the differential coefficients with respect to it are called ode Ex-dy/dx=x ka spuare 2–1 Differential equations which involve two or more independent variables and partial derivatives with respect to them are called pde.
